newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: APEC summit key to ongoing trade reforms-Australia.
newsitem.headline: APEC summit key to ongoing trade reforms-Australia.

text.p: Key Asia-Pacific economies should take the lead in maintaining the worldwide push towards free trade at their annual summit later this month, a senior Australian government official said on Thursday.

The official, who did not want to be named, said the Asia-Pacific Economic Co-operation (APEC) forum summit in the Philippines should signal the members' commitment to freer trade at a time when other countries were backsliding.
"The meeting from our point of view is important because of what it can do in terms of keeping the momentum of trade liberalisation going at a global level," the official told reporters.
"The fact is, we can't assume that ... the momentum of trade liberalisation will continue globally -- in fact, the natural tendency is for that to slow down, if not be reversed."
APEC's 18 members are due to present their blueprint in Manila for achieving the group's historic free trade pact, struck in Indonesia in 1994.
That agreement commits developed APEC members to axing trade barriers by 2010, with developing economies doing so by 2020.
Australia has also expressed concern about backsliding on free trade gains under the Uruguay Round of trade talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).
Ministers from the World Trade Organisation, which replaced GATT, are due to meet in Singapore next month for fresh talks.
"Everyone was looking for a breather," the Australian official said, "but obviously it's in our interest to try to get the dynamic moving again.

"APEC offers a very good opportunity to do that because the APEC members are probably amongst the most committed liberalisers -- they still see it as being very much in their own economic interest to continue the process of liberalisation.
"This helps at a time when other parts of the world may be not so keen."

APEC groups Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, Thailand and the United States.
